audio_caption: The scene opens with the sound of mixing or agitation, possibly in a laboratory setting. A male speaker with a somewhat formal tone introduces a reaction in a lab involving copper (II) sulfate and iron metal, anticipating the formation of pure copper and iron sulfate. He mentions that one of the reagents is a "limiting reagent." The mixing sound continues throughout the speech.

A male speaker begins by mentioning heating water and adding anhydrous copper sulfate, noting its almost-white color. He explains stirring it to dissolve it but avoids boiling. Once dissolved, the heat source is turned off, and he notes the color of the solution. The speaker moves the solution to a lab station to cool, accompanied by a distinct clinking sound. Finally, the audio closes with the sound of a tuning fork resonating.

The audio clip begins with one male speaker noting the appearance of iron metal and the color of a copper sulfate solution. Then he adds the iron to the solution. There is stirring or agitation of the solution while the speaker notes that stirring speeds up the reaction, and gives a reason why. A sound occurs and the male speaker continues stirring.

The audio clip begins with speech where the speaker mentions stirring "several minutes" after which "copper product" has settled to the bottom, leaving a "blue solution" behind. The speaker then points out that the bottom of the beaker has a "nice copper color." The speaking tone is informational. It seems to be a single male speaker.

The audio begins with a male speaker stating that they need to filter their product, and to do that they need filter paper. He then mentions obtaining a piece of filter paper, stating its mass as "1.50 grams." After this, the speaker describes how to fold the filter paper in half, twice, in order to make it fit into a funnel.

The clip begins with a male speaker describing a process, mentioning "if I've done that" and then "if I pinch three layers of the filter paper" and proceeding to explain how to fold it into a cone shape to fit into a funnel. He then instructs to let it rest in place. He states, "I can use some distilled water," followed by the sound of water being poured. Lastly, he states "and force it into the funnel."

The audio clip begins with a male speaker introducing a product and pouring it into a funnel. He mentions that "our solid copper" will be trapped in the filter paper. He then adds distilled water to make sure the product gets out of a beaker and rinses the sides of the beaker, stating that "the more copper I can get in my filter paper, the higher my percent yield." Following this, there's a distinct click sound.

The clip begins with someone stating that they "filtered all the water out of the mixture" and are left with "only copper in our filter paper." The speaker has a neutral tone. It sounds like a single speaker, potentially male.

The clip features a single male speaker, advising to let a filter paper dry overnight for accurate weighing. He also suggests noting the color of the remaining solution to determine the limiting and excess reagents. He describes carefully removing the filter paper and laying it flat in a fume hood for drying. His tone is informative and instructive.  The audio contains background sounds of laboratory equipment, suggesting a science lab setting.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing a chemical process. He mentions allowing a "copper product" to dry overnight, placing it on a balance, and determining its mass. He specifies that the final mass, "3.96 grams", includes the mass of the "copper product plus the filter paper". To find the mass of the copper, he advises listeners to "subtract the filter paper from the final mass". The speaker sounds informative and instructional.
